Well... I have been reading a few of the reviews on this game and gotta say y'all got something wrong in the head.

The game has a smaller base cost so people can actually try it, not like other dumb AAA games that launch unfinshed and filled with bugs at 90$ prices. The cost just allows the devs to keep working on the game since there is no big investors or whatever else bigger companies have. The whole game (bundle), as in all the classes and the last *not required/irrelevant* act, costs somewhere around 30-35$ at the time of this review (incl. the base game), this while on sale which is like 4+ months of the year. The price can be even lower too, I bought the bundle for 17.21$ back in March and I'm only missing the last class (Bard).
The microtransactions everyone is freaking out about are just skins, by which logic literally any "free" ARPG on steam is filled with. And isn't pay2win like some mobile games *cough cough* Torchlight *cough cough*.
And about the inventory expansion and bank/chest tabs, it's the same with PoE, where without the currency tab which is like 10$ you legit can't play the endgame as your currency will fill all the free tabs very quickly. On here tough I never ever filled more then the 2 basic inventory tabs unless was picking everything (which would be dumb to do), and you can very quickly drop a portal back to town and deposit whatever you want to keep. I do have an extra one from the bundle but mostly only used it to keep 1-2 items to switch in case I ever wanted to do so. And for the bank tabs you have 1 entire tab PER CHARACTER, on top of the shared one, so technically you have 22 total tabs since you can make 21 characters when buying the game. And for people complaining about being 21 character slots while there is 23 classes, believe me, you will never play all of them at once, and like in any season based ARPG you will play 1-2 maybe 3 classes in a season then at some point you will have to delete the classes from the "Standard" server. But with campaign being so quick this will never really be a problem.

Now for the actual review:
The game has a nice and quick campaign and you can play with up to 3 friends (4 total/game), and if someone is willing to help you rush it you can be done in ~30mins, this is especially nice when you want to grind the endgame and not be stuck on only 1 class (like PoE 2, where is annoyingly long imo, though nice).
And like any other ARPG ever, the endgame just consists in running something on repeat, whether they are codexes, boss rush/farm, dungeons or whatever else is there.
I personally enjoy all types of ARPGs and love this grindy aspect, where your heart skips a beat when something super rare just dropped, or enjoy seeing myself rich on the trade server.
The class diversity is also really nice, you have a lot of classes with plenty of skills to choose from, it's basically impossible to not find a class you love playing.
I give the game an easy 9/10, and I know the devs just keep cooking more and more cool seasons and updates.
Good luck and have fun gamers!

TLDR:  The reviews about the devs are unmerited.  The game has a lot of depth to it not visible at first glance.  There's a lot to do in the end game.  There are 23 classes all VERY unique from one another.   For first time players, remember to equip a pet, they pick up a lot of items for you.

All these negative reviews about "Toxic Dev team" is ridiculous.  I've spoken to the majority of the Dev team in the discord and they have always been responsive and listen.  Several QOL features I asked them about were added the very next season release.  That being said, on to the actual review.

Hero Siege is a deceptive game.  It used to be a completely different genre long ago and has since become a full fleshed out ARPG.  There are 23? classes, each with their own very unique play style.  Each main skill has a small passive tree that has small nodes as well as 4 unique large modifiers that in most cases completely changes how the skill functions.  

The gearing is fun and pretty straight forward as far as base stats go, but there are things like triggered skills, passive abilities, whole new usable skills etc. that get mixed into the gear as well.   There is plenty of gear to get you into endgame, and then a TON of chase items to go after from many different sources.   After you get what you were looking for, there are several ways to add to and modify the gear using crafting items and armor imbuement in the long run.  It has a way of making your character feel complete and ready while also leaving you room to constantly upgrade.

There is a Diablo 2 Esq rune word system for those familiar.  Socket specific runes into a white item in a specific order and it will convert it into what is essentially a unique item. There are a LOT of runewords.  The nice thing extra on this, any stats on the white item are also added to the rune word item.  It is possible to get some really nice high stats on white gear, making those items, despite being the lowest rarity, worthwhile to keep for yourself or to sell on the auction house.

The endgame has consists of boss farming, uber bosses, Wormholes with infinitely scaling difficulty, Chaos towers that are essentially 10 floor survival levels with select-able monster/loot modifiers, Chaos zone farming (after beating the bosses on hell+ difficulties chaos zones appear with unique modifiers on them. They can also be hand crafted), challenge dungeons, , rifts to random increased difficulty zones, a shadow realm with a special vendor and special boss fight, and even keys to special levels with their own unique loot rewards.  There's a good bit to keep you going.

I've played every major ARPG to speak of with thousands of hours in POE1, POE2, Last Epoch, etc.   Hero siege, despite looking more like a cartoon at first glance, definitely holds it's own against all these titles.  I actually find myself going back to it more often than all the others with their most recent updates.   Coming up in December they are even adding a massive 1100+ node passive tree and even a loot passive tree. I am HUGELY looking forward to it.

This game used to be a lot of fun. Back in Season 1, it had a simple but addictive loop — kill enemies, collect artifacts with cool effects, and speedrun through waves before starting fresh on the next run. It was fast, satisfying, and genuinely unique.

It originally felt like a game in the spirit of The Binding of Isaac — simple, replayable, and full of cool item synergies. But now, it looks and plays more like a cheap Diablo knockoff. They could’ve just kept the original gameplay loop, added multiplayer, and expanded the artifact system with more item combos. Instead, they completely changed the formula, adding clunky ARPG mechanics and pay-to-play systems that ruined what made the original so fun.

Now it’s a completely different game. It barely resembles what I originally bought. The core gameplay that made it special is gone, and there’s no way to revert to earlier builds or replay the classic version. Honestly, it feels like false advertising at this point.

What we have now isn’t the game I paid for — it’s bloated, paywalled garbage. The developer clearly doesn’t listen to the community, and instead of gutting the old version, they should’ve just made Hero Siege 2 instead.

I wouldn’t recommend anyone buy this game in its current state. Spend your money on something like The Binding of Isaac or Heroes of Hammerwatch — you’ll have a much better time and be supporting developers who actually care about their players.

What used to be a fun little Diablo-esque dungeon runner/rogue-lite is now nothing like what they originally advertised and released.
